results.content:
I like that he builds a 'real' app stack over the course and that the changes in each lecture are small enough that you can keep up manually typing things in and testing.  Also nice that he provides diffs and complete snapshots at every step, so if you want to skip ahead to a particular section, it would still be easy to start at any point.

I'm planning on taking what I've learned to write an Ansible config for an architecture practical lab exam for work.  I've got full confidence that I know enough now to get it automated and repeatable.

The only trouble I had with the course were a few syntax changes between when this course was written, and the current version of Ansible (2.6.1 on my system).  Some places needed to be quoted, or didn't need to be in {{ }} brackets anymore. "when" statements in particular.

Overall, great course, with a good mix of theory, practical nuts-n-bolts, and info on where to dig deeper into each topic.

results.content:
It was a great session, I did learn a lot of new things about Ansible.

The instructor also sounds having in-depth knowledge and experience in Infrastructure deployment and administration. I am looking if Chris has any other course here.

Few things I was hoping for same or next courses are:
- detailed setup infrastructure, like here docker was used. I also prefer to use docker container as they are easy to spawn and destroy with minimal requirements, hence I am using docker container.
During the lecture, while setting up the load balancer, my app didn't run at first and I have to debug it by going inside to container to restart the nginx server, reason was here we are using webservers hostname in nginx configs, while we never added webservers ips in hosts file. I believe either we should take care of this while writing ansible playbooks (which I have tried from ansible but it say access denied not sure how to do that yet), or remind that these particular node/container/target host should communicate with each other.
I did saw the appendix video, and by architecture it was clear, but it did took my time and patience.

- more real-life examples.
- more scenario which people are facing, as this was mastering ansible not basic.

Also, thanks udemy, for such great courses and instructors. Can you also do something for interview preparations.

results.content:
The instructor really knows ansible and can explain it well, however the course is too dated and its hard to follow along.

I'm using ansible 2, and the course was made for ansible 1 apparently.

Also, the course works on building web servers and database servers, and he uses ubuntu or debian, rather than a more common and popular OS for those CentOS7/RHEL7.

There are also some differences if you try to do it with a cloud environment such as AWS.

The main problem with the outdated content is each lab builds on the previously  lab, so once you hit a wall on one, none of the future labs will work.

If Chris updates this for Ansible 2, CentOS7 and AWS it would easily be a 5 star course.

results.content:
The instructor acknowledged that not all production environments are homogeneous (i.e. same OS in same config on all) - but did not touch on how Ansible caters for that.

For instance: he makes extensive use of the "apt" module to ensure that packages are available on the target system - but no explanation for what happens if apt is not available (i.e. on RHEL/CentOS).
What if my one server is RHEL, my other Debian, but both need apache? Must there be two playbooks? Do I put an ignore failure condition if the host OS doesn't support a package manager and then just configure for all possible package managers?

No mention is made for how to orchestrate Windows servers either, just a comment that it's not recommended to try and run the Control node from a Windows host...

All-in-all, a great primer... but definitely not mastery
results.content_html:
The instructor acknowledged that not all production environments are homogeneous (i.e. same OS in same config on all) - but did not touch on how Ansible caters for that.

For instance: he makes extensive use of the "apt" module to ensure that packages are available on the target system - but no explanation for what happens if apt is not available (i.e. on RHEL/CentOS).
What if my one server is RHEL, my other Debian, but both need apache? Must there be two playbooks? Do I put an ignore failure condition if the host OS doesn't support a package manager and then just configure for all possible package managers?

No mention is made for how to orchestrate Windows servers either, just a comment that it's not recommended to try and run the Control node from a Windows host...

All-in-all, a great primer... but definitely not mastery

I think as time goes on the course could be periodically updated to reflect some of the changes that Ansible gets updated with. I know at the time of course creation Ansible 1.9 was being used but when I started the course the latest version of Ansible was 2.4

results.content:
So far, the course is helpfully guiding me step-by-step through the basics of Ansible, but...

But I found in more than one occasion that the syntax presented in the examples was incorrect (possibly due to the course being recorded for an older version of Ansible?) and required some troubleshooting to fix it - this was, after all, a good exercise, but the fact that the syntax was incorrect in the first place is annoying.

I am also finding that some elements of the syntax are introduced without proper explanation - nothing I won't eventually be able to work out, but some concepts are given for granted, rather than explaining why they are used in a specific context.

I still value the course as an introduction to Ansible, but the accuracy of the content and quality of the explanation could be better.

Interesting stuff, but some hard to follow points. Ansible has changed since then and couple of times you will be stuck unless you read Q&A, Google or find some other way to fix issues.

Also in Vagrantfile there were no hostnames set and that caused issues in one part.

Another thing what makes it a little bit hard to follow is that instructor screen size is too small in many videos and lines goes longer than what can fit to the screen. In practise when the instructor goes to the end of line you must pause the video so you can see the end of the line and write it to your own editor. Sometimes almost immediately when the line is on the end video goes away from the screen so have to rewind back which is quite annoying.

Still the most important thing is that I have learn lots of stuff from these videos and it made my understand why it would be handy to use this instead of BASH-scripts which works also very well in almost all the cases.

results.content:
The presenter is low-key and seems to be focused on transmitting the information efficiently, and is not trying to entertain or present a showy personality. This is everything I hope for in a presenter.

After completing the course, I am upgrading the rating from 4.5 stars to 5 stars. The content was communicated in an understandable way, obviously intended for an audience who already have experience with linux and advanced systems administration, and no time was wasted in efforts to engage the audience with extraneous information. 

The course was very step-wise, and dense in information - I found myself pausing the video often in order to keep up with my note-taking, which is exactly what I hope for - no wasted time, lots of useful information.

I hope than any future courses I take from udemy will use this same presenter, or a presenter with a similar teaching style.

results.content:
Thank you for your Ansible class.  I was able to take what you gave me and put it to work immediately.  A few months after completing your course, I was asked to create an Ansible playbook to install and configure Nagios for one of our customers, who has a highly customized network setup. 

Done!  And I couldn't have done it without you.

Some things are not as elegant as I would like.  For example, I know there is a better way to iterate through a series of files and run the replace module multiple times per file.  But what I wrote works.  

I have many years experience as a UNIX/Linux Systems Administrator.  In some ways, I'm kind of old school, but I just love learning new tricks!!

Thanks, Chris!

results.title: Wish I could give it more than five stars
results.content:
Really really good.  Course is an excellent interactive walkthrough of the core of ansible and some best practice recommendations.  The hands-on approach of bringing up a multi-VM stack of loadbalancer, web, and database systems via ansible and incrementally building it up is an excellent way of spinning up on the DevOps tools and mindset.

I particularly liked the ability to download the ansible files at 'that' point in time in almost every lecture as the course progressed in order to find my typos/omissions, and the fact that the code 'worked' as-is all the way through the lectures was greatly appreciated.

Hope there's a future advanced ansible class.  It was that good.

results.content: S

To the point with just enough info.

Edit:  I'm dropping the stars down a bit.  There's a good amount of outdated syntax - enough for examples to break and make you hunt around to see what's wrong.

It's really a shame because the instructor's methodology is great.  The explanations are good and the examples are well thought out.  I've been able to use some of the examples directly because he uses such a common architecture/pattern.  

The bottom line is as of this review (1/2018), it's still a good course, but be prepared to stop and read through the Q&A's.

results.content:
The course is pretty good.  There are items just glossed over that make it hard to understand some things. I realize the class is ansible but since your using docker, docker-machine, etc.  Some discussion in how all this works would really help. The appendix is great but there really is no mention to go there and also no mention of what pieces to so very hard to understand how all the machines, containers, etc.  Not asking for a full day or anything but a quick discussion.

The other thing is for some reason the example is showing different results.  I see nothing in comparing the current state of directory to what I have.  It would be good if you updated the information in the current state directory to reflect the current version of sensible and just put a comment. 

For example in the ansible 2.0 you have to modify the sites.   

It is not obvious to someone learning if they did something wrong or if something changed.  When you go out to discussion area there is much info that is maybe close, etc but does not really explain why?   

Do not get me wrong I learned a lot and feel I can tackle what I set out but I still have questions in my mind that I feel just another minute or two here and there would have really made this experience excellent.

UPDATE:  I am updating my review.  This couse is fantastic. At the time I was thrown by some of the small syntax issues.  Instructor updated explanations about the templateing languages etc. involved which now makes perfect sense. Highly recommend this course.

results.content: This is a very good class on Ansible. If you want, or have to get up an running with Ansible it's worth every cent. The Teacher does not have a very dynamic presentation style, but if you are patient and go through the exercises with him you will learn Ansible. Warning1: You will run into issues with some of the later labs if you are running the most up to date release of Ansible. I have not seen the Instructor address this but other students provide great notes on how to fix these errors. Warning2: the Instructor provides a few different options for setting up the lab environment for the class, which is confusing. He provides a very cool Vagrant setup file but doesn't really guide you on how to use it so you will have spend a few minutes on youtube to learn the basics of setting up a Vagrant environment. One  more thing, the lab works best if you run a GUI on your Linux Server being used for the control of your Ansible environment . This allows you to use a text editor throughout the exercises shown in the class.

results.content:
This course was a very good introduction to Ansible.  Chris makes it simple enough to follow, and the examples are not overly complicated.  I did run into issues with mysql.  I used Vagrant, and had created a "small" VM for the db server, and had issues with starting mysql, and it turned out that I needed to change the VM to have more RAM (I started with 256MB, and ended up with 1GB).  Also, the course is based on Ansible 1.9.x, but current ansible 2.0.x has differences that I had to adjust to reflect the results provided in the course.

At the end of the day, I enjoyed it, and will start from scratch again, and go through the whole course at least one more time

results.content: Completed.  This is a VERY well done course!  I took this without knowing anything about Ansible, and now I feel comfortable enough to start using it in my work environment.  Chris Lunsford does a great job explaining, step-by-step, how Ansible works, and how to build on each step.  He patiently explains the concept for each lecture followed by hands-on tasks. It is obvious that he has planned what he wants to say beforehand, and how he will illustrate the topic of the lecture.    The example environment is well planned, and includes several systems with a variety of functions.  (I would suggest watching the lectures in the appendix before starting Unit 3 if you are not already familiar with the subjects they cover.)  He also shows you where to find information online to continue learning.

results.content:
This course was definitely helpful in getting me the basic understanding of the different parameters involved in Ansible. I feel a lot more comfortable in my own ability to parse through playbooks created by colleagues to determine what is going on under the covers. 

In my own experience of this course, YMMV, the video is sort of choppy as if buffering. I'm on a 1000base backbone so I don't believe my issue to be bandwidth related but unfortunately I don't have the means of testing connectivity elsewhere. 
My other issue isn't so much with the material, but is more related to Ansible and how newer versions break existing code which makes for a painful migration to newer versions and is definitely something to think about before deploying this architecture.

results.title: Simple and straight forward
results.content:
Chris effectively builds concepts one on top of another, and will re-iterate or re-explain concepts that haven't been visited in a while so that you don't ever feel lost.

One suggestion is to have a section for [best] practices around reusing the same ansible project or set of playbooks for multiple environments. For instance, how we might restructure our inventory, variables, and vault files (or lack of) for local development where you may want to have less VMs with more responsibility (eg, one VM is the control server, app server, and database server) in order to save on resources. While at the same time being able to reuse those same playbooks for staging and production.

results.title: Well structured and useful tips
results.content:
The course is really well structured and easy to follow along. There is also plenty of practical and helpful tips along the way. I also appreciate having downloadable code snapshots for every lecture, although I recommend writing the code yourself. The only friction point for me was getting the environment working in the beginning due to some permissions bug in docker preventing me from SSH-ing into the containers, which took some time to troubleshoot (moving the chmod command below the chmod command in the Dockerfile solved it).
Overall, this course was a very effective and fun way to learn Ansible and I feel I can confidently start using this new knowledge right away for any of my projects.
results.content_html:

The rate of flow of information was appropriate (i.e. decent signal to noise ratio), the presenter wasn't boring, patronising or opinionated, just clearly knowledgeable, coherent and clear.  I felt the rate of useful information did start to fall off about 2/3 of the way through, but that's because it becomes more specific (and less guaranteed to be relevant to a specific viewer) and I think that's probably unavoidable.

I'm fairly easily bored and I made it through to the very end, and worked along with some VMs on the side which helped solidify the concepts.  All in all, the course took longer than I expected but I guess that just makes it good value for money ;)

results.content: The course is comprehensive and videos are not long. However, I have several points about this course. Firstly, explanations lack visual support. Just listening someone explaining is quite hard to understand, specially when you are not an expert in the subject. Secondly, videos should be self-contained. This course has many videos and the instructor cannot expect that everyone is going to watch all classes at once. If one watch a video a day, it is quite hard to follow because there is a need to remember exactly what has been done in the last 3 or 4 videos. Thirdly, the instructor overlooked some fundamental configuration (e.g., access keys for ssh) for getting started with ansible. I noted that there is a video in the end, but this configuration is necessary at the beginning. Finally, it is almost impossible to watch from video 36 onwards. Videos freeze every 4 seconds. I had to wait till the video load completely in order to watch.

results.content:
This course is by far the best hands-on course I've come across. I've bought books, watched free youtube tutorials, scoured stackexhange, and read documentation until my eyes bled.

Chris has managed to put together an engaging course that covers all the basics and more while setting up a real-world scenario lab from beginning to end. It's obvious he spent a lot of time putting together the material as each new concept introduced has an explicit purpose to forwarding the lab.

Even though this is a beginners course, I highly recommend going over the Ansible documentation and looking at a few example playbooks before starting this course to familiarize yourself with some of the concepts.

Also, Chris is running Ansible 1.9. The current release is 2.1. You will run into issues/errors if you install the current version. GitHub is your friend for work arounds. It's annoying to stop and troubleshoot when the behavior you get does not match Chris', but you will learn even more about Ansible reading through the issues at GitHub than just following along with Chris.

*Quick tip, for sudo timeout issues, set the %sudo group in the sudoers file on the app devices to NOPASSWD:ALL. This was the biggest issue a ran into running Ansible 2.1.

results.content:
Nice and valuable information presented so far via a very useful use case (setting up a cluster consisting of 1 load balancer, 2 web servers and 1 db server using 1 control machine).

More (info)graphics and visualization instead of the lecturer's face would be helpful (e.g. when listing pre-requisites for following along, how to set up the environment etc).

It is also worth mentioning that some python (mostly) and django (less important) knowledge helps a bit to follow along (the course uses concepts such as virtualenv, pip and jinja templates which are used in Django - from all these concepts of course, only the jinja templates are essential to Ansible - the rest are used for example's sake)

results.content:
One third into the course.
The setup of the work environment for the course doesn't have a step by step, though it could be in the appendix, which I have not checked out.

The course assumes some experience with linux and virtualization, mainly Ubuntu, Vagrant, Virtualbox and some Bash, which is not an issue for me. The scrips to set up the work environment and follow along are also provided as a resource and they are very basic and easy to understand.

The instructor is very knowledgeable, the course is fast paced, but well laid out, easy to understand, full of quality information and riddled with tips from the instructor's experience and where to find more information related to the subjects presented.

Overall I'd say, this is an excellent course for anyone wishing to learn Ansible.

results.content: The lessons are ok but the initial environment setup instructions are terrible.  I know a trainer cannot be expected to explain all the steps for all students possible starting points and computer systems, linux, mac, windows, etc. but at the very least he should give better instructions to set up an environment with Docker like the trainer actually configured for his own machine in his lectures.  The appendix instructions on Docker are cryptic and vague.  They should be clearer on what to expect during install and the very basics of how docker works would be nice.  For example, we don't actually need to download Unbuntu iso images manually, the Docker setup does that for us.  What happens after the install completes? We should have been warned the Docker VM will just hang after completion but the containers are up and running and thats the EXPECTED outcome... How do we get ssh working for our docker containers? etc, etc.  Its true, some of these questions are answered in the QandA but you have to hunt through each lectures QandA to find them.  Why not put that information in the environment configuration steps? Most importantly, he completely skips the explanation of how he configured the NFS with Docker containers like he has in his environment for the lectures. (Which it actually never was NFS. I was informed it was an additional flag added to the Docker exec command so it just looks like an NFS file share in the lessons)  Why not show the terminal command somewhere so we can do it instead of making us ask for it!? I spent over 4+ hours attempting initial setup on a Mac like the instructor has using both Docker and Vagrant and I still don't have it working properly. Very frustrated with the explanation to get the environment working and I work in IT....
results.content_html: The lessons are ok but the initial environment setup instructions are terrible. I know a trainer cannot be expected to explain all the steps for all students possible starting points and computer systems, linux, mac, windows, etc. but at the very least he should give better instructions to set up an environment with Docker like the trainer actually configured for his own machine in his lectures. The appendix instructions on Docker are cryptic and vague. They should be clearer on what to expect during install and the very basics of how docker works would be nice. For example, we don't actually need to download Unbuntu iso images manually, the Docker setup does that for us. What happens after the install completes? We should have been warned the Docker VM will just hang after completion but the containers are up and running and thats the EXPECTED outcome... How do we get ssh working for our docker containers? etc, etc. Its true, some of these questions are answered in the QandA but you have to hunt through each lectures QandA to find them. Why not put that information in the environment configuration steps? Most importantly, he completely skips the explanation of how he configured the NFS with Docker containers like he has in his environment for the lectures. (Which it actually never was NFS. I was informed it was an additional flag added to the Docker exec command so it just looks like an NFS file share in the lessons) Why not show the terminal command somewhere so we can do it instead of making us ask for it!? I spent over 4+ hours attempting initial setup on a Mac like the instructor has using both Docker and Vagrant and I still don't have it working properly. Very frustrated with the explanation to get the environment working and I work in IT....
